facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 560 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CIVIl. APPEAL No. 560 or 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 11, 1961 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 295 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 295, of 1958.

facts.text: Governor of Madras issued notification on August 4, 1956 under sub-section 4 of s.64 of Madras Act XIX of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1956, the Governor of Madras issued a numberification in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by sub-section  4  of s. 64 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act. 1951  Madras Act XIX of 1951

facts.text: Notification continued Notification No. 638 dated May 25, 1937 for five years from September 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: directing that numberification No. 638, dated the 25th May, 1937. relating to Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple, Tiruvarur, Nagapattanam Taluk, Tanjor District, be companytinued for a period of five years from September 30, 1956.

facts.text: Earlier notification issued by State of Madras under clause b of sub-section 5 of s.65A of Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1926 (Madras Act II of 1927).

anchor.surface_text: The earlier numberification which was thus companytinued had itself been issued by the respondent State of Madras in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by clause  b  of sub-section  5  of s.65A of the Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1926  Madras Act 1I of 1927

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Madras High Court challenging validity of 1956 notification.

anchor.surface_text: By a writ petition filed by the appellant, Sri-la-Sri Subramania Desika Gnana Sambanda Pandarasannadhi, Hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai of the temple in question, in the High Court of Madras the validity of this latter numberification was challenged.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed writ petition on August 11, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rejected the pleas raised by the appellant in support of his case that the impugned numberification is invalid, and has dismissed the writ petition filed by him.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Sri Thiyagarajaswami Temple is in Tiruvarur, Thanjavur District.

anchor.surface_text: In the town of Tiruvarur in Thanjavur Dist. there is an ancient temple. The Presiding Deity is Sri Thyagarajaswami.

facts.text: Temple has specific endowments called Kattalais, including Rajan Kattalai, with hereditary trustees.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of specific endowments called Kattalais with specific reference to special services in the temple, its festivities and several charities in glorification of the principal deity, have however been made in respect of this temple. It is said that there are 13 such Kattalais, the important amongst them being Rajan Kattalai

facts.text: Trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai vests in head of Dharmapuram mutt.

anchor.surface_text: The trusteeship of Rajan Kattalai vests in the head of the Dharmapuram mutt in the Thanjavur district.

facts.text: Suit filed in 1910 under s.92 CPC in Sub-Court Thanjavur, scheme settled and confirmed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: As a result. in 1910, a suit was flied under s.92 of the Code of Civil Procedure for the settlement of a scheme to manage the affairs of the temple in the Sub-Court at Thanjavur. A scheme was accordingly settled. and when the matter was taken in appeal, the High Court substantially companyfirmed the said scheme

facts.text: Notification issued on May 25, 1937 under Chapter VI-A of 1927 Act.

anchor.surface_text: on May 25, 1937, a numberification was issued. To this numberification we have already referred.

facts.text: Executive Officer appointed by Board on July 12, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this numberification, an Executive Officer was appointed by the Board on July 12, 1937.

facts.text: Board defined powers of Executive Officer on July 30, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: On July 30, 1937, the Board defined the powers of the Executive Officer and directed him to take charge and be in possession of the temple and the various Kattalais attached thereto.

facts.text: Pandarasannadhi filed Suit No. 20 of 1938 in Madras High Court challenging 1937 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The Pandarasannadhi of the Dharmapuram Mutt who was then the hereditary Trustee of the Rajan Kattalai instituted S. No. 20 of 1938 in the Madras High Court for a declaration that the said numberification was illegal

facts.text: Compromise decree passed on August 1, 1940 in Suit No. 20 of 1938.

anchor.surface_text: This companypromise decree was passed on August 1, 1940, and since then, the administration of the Kattalai in question has been companyducted jn accordance with the terms of this decree.

facts.text: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1951 (Act XIX of 1951) came into force on September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This latter Act came into force on September 30. 1951. Section 5 of this Act repealed the earlier Act of 1927.

facts.text: Amending Act No. IX of 1956 passed, substituting s.64(4).

anchor.surface_text: In 1956, another Amending Act  No. IX of 1956  was passed. Section 2 of this Amending Act substituted a new sub-section in the place of s.64 4

facts.text: Madras Act XXII of 1959 came into force on January 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: a new Act had companye into force  Madras Act XXII of 1959 . This Act came into operation on January I, 1960.

facts.text: High Court held proceedings under s.64(4) are quasi-judicial requiring opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has found in favour of the appellant that the proceedings authorised to be taken under s.64 4  are in the nature of quasi-judicial proceedings.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, directed writ quashing 1956 notification.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court, and direct that an appropriate writ or order be issued quashing the numberification issued by the respondent State on August 4, 1956.

facts.text: No notice given to appellant before issuing 1956 notification.

anchor.surface_text: the numberification was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier numberification should number be extended.

issues.text: Whether the trusteeship of the Rajan Kattalai is a right of property under Article 19(1)(f) of the Constitution and Section 64 of the Act is unconstitutional as it empowers the State to take away that right arbitrarily.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that the trusteeship of the Rajan Kattalai being hereditary in the head of the Dharmapuram Mutt. is a right of property under Art. 19 i  f  of the Constitution, and since s.64 of the Act empowers the respondent State to take away that right of property in an arbitrary and capricious manner.

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification under Section 64(4) is invalid because it was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier notification should not be extended.

anchor.surface_text: the numberification was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier numberification should number be extended. and that made the numberification invalid.

issues.text: Whether the order passed under Section 64(4) is a quasi-judicial order requiring compliance with the principles of natural justice unlike orders under Sections 64(1)-(3).
Whether the impugned notification would automatically expire on September 30, 1961 rendering quashing unnecessary.
Whether the plea regarding violation of natural justice was raised in the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court thought that this specific point had number been taken by the appellant in his writ petition that is why it was number inclined to allow it.

arguments.claim: The trusteeship of the Rajan Kattalai is a right of property under Art. 19(1)(f) and s.64 empowers State to take it arbitrarily making it constitutionally invalid

Cited precedent Shri Radeshyam Khare distinguishes ss.53A and 57 of C.P. Act analogously to s.64(3) and 64(4)
arguments.court_reasoning: Precedent inapplicable as process under s.64(4) same as s.64(3) unlike the distinguished sections

arguments.claim: New Act XXII of 1959 s.72(7) prevents automatic expiry of notification

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 7  of this Act provides that any numberification published under sub-s. 1  or sub-s. 3  of s. 64 of Act XIX of 1951 before the commencement this Act shall be as valid as if such numberification had been published under this Act.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the order passed under s.64(4) is a quasi-judicial order and can be legitimately passed only after complying with the principles of natural justice by giving notice to the trustee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: The process under s.64(4) involves considering relevant facts on each occasion similar to s.64(3), requiring hearing the trustee; respondent's cited precedent distinguished as inapplicable.

holdings.text: The impugned notification under s.64(4) is invalid as it was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier notification should not be extended.

anchor.surface_text: the notification was issued without giving an opportunity to the appellant to show cause why the earlier notification should not be extended, and that made the notification invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obligatory under natural justice for quasi-judicial proceedings under s.64(4) to provide notice and hearing before extension.

holdings.text: The specific plea regarding violation of natural justice by not providing opportunity was raised by the appellant in the affidavit-in-rejoinder in the writ petition.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea expressly taken in affidavit-in-rejoinder; not disputed by respondents.

holdings.text: The impugned notification does not automatically expire on September 30, 1961, as continued by Section 72(7) of Madras Act XXII of 1959.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 72(7) deems prior notifications valid under new Act, preventing automatic expiry; High Court ignored this provision.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; High Court order set aside; writ to issue quashing the notification dated August 4, 1956 issued under s.64(4).
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on both grounds for refusing writ; notification invalid for non-compliance with natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Ramanathan Chettiar v. Balayee Ammal 2 . In that case, the High Court rejected the contention of one of the Kattalai trustees that subject to the performance of services, the endowments in question had to be treated as his property

precedents.cited_proposition: all the Kattalais were appendages of the temple though each Kattalaidar was a separate trustee, there was no question of private ownership

precedents.citation: Shri Radeshyam Khare Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Others.  1

anchor.surface_text: Shri Radeshyam Khare Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Others.  1  In that case, it was held that ss. 53A and 57 of the C.P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, differed materially in their scope and effect

precedents.case_name: Shri Radeshyam Khare Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: ss. 53A and 57 of the C.P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, differed materially in their scope and effect, and that the nature of the orders which can be passed under the two respective sections was not the same, whereas action under s.53A required acting judicially, the same could not be said about s.57
precedents.cited_holding: whereas in taking action under s.53A the State Government was required to act judicially, the same could not be said to be true about s.57
